text:
I’m thinking like the 2D node wire concepts that I’ve seen while researching but in 3D space with your own grouping logic (you can grab and move things around) as well as maybe hand drawn notes and symbols in space?

Then you can follow those connections to zip along to other areas. Not sure if “nodes” or “forms” will contain other entities or if they’ll link to things further down in the 3D space, so the program is actually visualised as a tree :thinking_face:  none of this is solid in my head yet, just thoughts.

The main thing I want is visibility into the entire programs execution, you can just see the values travelling between things (real time and slow motion would be configurable). If I built it on ClojureScript or something I’ll have time travel for the state of the program as it executes, which may allow pause/rewind/change/resume in 3D space.

text: No idea how this sort of thing will scale, it’ll probably be super weird. But I still want to give it a go and see what I can come up with! I’m thinking about being able to attach more cameras in the world that you can lock to one of your controllers, that allows you to at a glance see some group of nodes and what state they’re in.

text:
Hi all!
I'm a web applications developer. I'm really excited by the idea of bringing programming to a less technical audience, in a way that they can easily understand, whilst being based on rigorous paradigms (without making a big song and dance about that), and having their work translate down to something a professional programmer could (and would be glad to) inherit.
I've been catching up on the podcast slowly but surely and it seems like this is a community that has much in common with me. Glad to be here!

elements.text:

I've been catching up on the podcast slowly but surely and it seems like this is a community that has much in common with me. Glad to be here!

text:
Hi Xandor!
I am looking forward to learning more about your ideas regarding simplifying web development. Brother and I have been working on a project (<https://wasp-lang.dev/> - it is still very early) where we are looking to achieve very similar thing -> we would like to make web app development much simpler for developers first, and then possibly also for non-developers, while keeping up with the current ecosystem. We think way to do this might be by building a (declarative) domain specific language specialized for web app development.
Let me know if this seems interesting, and I hope we will anyway have some discussion on this topic!

Let me know if this seems interesting, and I hope we will anyway have some discussion on this topic!

text:
Hi Martin! I've actually already seen your project and subscribed a while ago :slightly_smiling_face:
I like that your project is taking a declarative approach, I think it's easier to understand (assuming that the DSL reifies the _right abstraction_) for programmers and regular people in general.
I also have a vision of building stuff lower down the stack that would initially be useful to programmers, but what I'll build on that foundation in the future would be useful to non-programmers.
My vision is to first define a subset of JS that is purely functional. I've been able to do this to a fair degree using ESLint + Flow, but it doesn't go far enough, there are some serious gaps in Flow, such as no higher-kinded types, trouble understanding auto-curried functions (TypeScript is even _less_ capable in this regard). I may have to write my own typechecker :sweat_smile:
Then I'd like to take a leaf out of Luna's book and provide a visual way of representing code that conforms to this subset.
On top of this basis I may build declarative tools that work at a higher level.
I hadn't considered using a DSL.
Would be happy to chat more

Would be happy to chat more

text:
Oh great, glad to hear you subscribed :slightly_smiling_face:!

Exactly, that is why we are focusing on declarative approach for now, because we think it can be really simple to use. However, as you mentioned, it is important to pick the right abstractions so that the resulting DSL is simple, powerful, but also flexible enough, and that is tricky, we are focusing on that a lot at the moment, examining popular web frameworks in order to figure out the right abstractions. Also, not everything can be reasonably made declarative, so we are trying to figure out which features are good to describe in declarative fashion and which are not, and how to approach those down the road.

Standalone DSL also comes with its own set of problems -> all the support (IDE) that language needs, integration with existing languages and solutions, ...

It seems we share the big vision, although we have different approaches - very exciting, I would be happy to share insights in the future!

I hope you don't mind me asking, what is the motivation for using a functional subset of JS? Is that to provide "safer"/simpler experience to developers? And/or is it to enable you to build the next step, the visual editor, on a good foundation that matches the visual way of representing the web app?
Also, what about solutions like Purescript? I am guessing you want to go with Javascript due to its popularity and how easy it is to use? That certainly makes sense, just wondering hm!

Btw. is there a way to follow your work, maybe somewhere to subscribe? If not I will just keep my eyes open here on FoC slack!

elements.text: Oh great, glad to hear you subscribed

!

However, as you mentioned, it is important to pick the right abstractions so that the resulting DSL is simple, powerful, but also flexible enough, and that is tricky, we are focusing on that a lot at the moment, examining popular web frameworks in order to figure out the right abstractions. Also, not everything can be reasonably made declarative, so we are trying to figure out which features are good to describe in declarative fashion and which are not, and how to approach those down the road.

Standalone DSL also comes with its own set of problems -> all the support (IDE) that language needs, integration with existing languages and solutions, ...

It seems we share the big vision, although we have different approaches - very exciting, I would be happy to share insights in the future!

I hope you don't mind me asking, what is the motivation for using a functional subset of JS? Is that to provide "safer"/simpler experience to developers? And/or is it to enable you to build the next step, the visual editor, on a good foundation that matches the visual way of representing the web app?
Also, what about solutions like Purescript? I am guessing you want to go with Javascript due to its popularity and how easy it is to use? That certainly makes sense, just wondering hm!

Btw. is there a way to follow your work, maybe somewhere to subscribe? If not I will just keep my eyes open here on FoC slack!

text:
> I hope you don't mind me asking, what is the motivation for using a functional subset of JS? Is that to provide "safer"/simpler experience to developers? And/or is it to enable you to build the next step, the visual editor, on a good foundation that matches the visual way of representing the web app?
It is for both of these reasons. Purely functional code is _very_ declarative, and thus is much better suited to a visual representation. I also want a safer/simpler experience for developers. The final vision I have is very ambitious, and may not be feasible for me to achieve. In working towards that vision, as I am building the pieces required for it, those pieces should be _independently useful_ for others. If I am not successful at any given point of my journey towards the final vision, what I have built up until that point should still be a net win for me in the work that I am doing at the time.

> Also, what about solutions like Purescript? I am guessing you want to go with Javascript due to its popularity and how easy it is to use? That certainly makes sense, just wondering hm!
I have considered compile-to-JS solutions, but I have issue with the community size, the ecosystem size, and the interop (they all promise 100% interop with JS on the box, but the reality is sometimes not so easy). Having said that, I'm likely to have the same challenges, there's more to interop than syntax, transpilation and module systems.
Mostly, though, the biggest concern I have is _inheritability_. I want a project that was created using my stack to be inheritable even to programmers that aren't necessarily familiar with FP. Although they may struggle to understand code they've inherited from me at first if they're not accustomed to FP, if that code is just a subset of JS, they can disable/remove the tooling that limits the code to a subset, and carry on with the project more easily using the paradigms that they are already familiar with.
I think this is one of the big issues with low-/no-code tools atm, they're walled gardens: there's literally _no code_, users are just configuring an instance of the vendor's platform. I want to build something that is genuinely inheritable, not just on paper, but in a very practical sense. (there are also many other problems with no-code that I hope to tackle).
It is for this reason that the entire stack needs to be open source, and its pieces should strive to be independently useful. I aim to build communities around each piece so that there will be some measure of support for those that _do_ inherit from me.
> Btw. is there a way to follow your work, maybe somewhere to subscribe? If not I will just keep my eyes open here on FoC slack!
Not yet. I've got some abstracts and notes written out (and the 1st stab at the ESLint + Flow config), but I haven't published anything.
I'll be taking paternity leave soon (:tada:), so I hope to put together something public-facing during that downtime.
I'll be sure to update here when that happens.

Having said that, I'm likely to have the same challenges, there's more to interop than syntax, transpilation and module systems.
Mostly, though, the biggest concern I have is

Although they may struggle to understand code they've inherited from me at first if they're not accustomed to FP, if that code is just a subset of JS, they can disable/remove the tooling that limits the code to a subset, and carry on with the project more easily using the paradigms that they are already familiar with.

no code

It is for this reason that the entire stack needs to be open source, and its pieces should strive to be independently useful. I aim to build communities around each piece so that there will be some measure of support for those that
do
inherit from me.
Btw. is there a way to follow your work, maybe somewhere to subscribe? If not I will just keep my eyes open here on FoC slack!

Not yet. I've got some abstracts and notes written out (and the 1st stab at the ESLint + Flow config), but I haven't published anything.
I'll be taking paternity leave soon (

), so I hope to put together something public-facing during that downtime.
I'll be sure to update here when that happens.

text:
Congrats :tada:  :slightly_smiling_face:!

What is your reason for inheritability, do you think that will be the common case with the audience you are targeting?
I believe there is a reason why inheritability is not present in no-code / low-code tools -> because it is hard to achieve, and at the end for most of them it is not that important, due to the use case they are catering to. But of course, if they did have inheritability, they could target more / different use cases, since developers could use it for prototyping and similar.

With Wasp, we have been looking at two things: inheritability and extensibility.
Extensibility would actually be interop that you mentioned -> can we allow people to combine/use existing parts of JS ecosystem together with Wasp, intermingled with Wasp?
And inheritability -> can we allow people to "eject" the code made by Wasp, so they can continue with it? We are mentioning that on our landing page.
In our case, extensibility is a must, while we would really like to have inheritability because it removes the "lock-in" effect, but we are aware it might be hard to achieve it, and its importance will be smaller and smaller as Wasp becomes more and more mature, so we are still evaluating how much time does it make sense to invest into inheritability.

elements.text: Congrats

!

What is your reason for inheritability, do you think that will be the common case with the audience you are targeting?
I believe there is a reason why inheritability is not present in no-code / low-code tools -> because it is hard to achieve, and at the end for most of them it is not that important, due to the use case they are catering to. But of course, if they did have inheritability, they could target more / different use cases, since developers could use it for prototyping and similar.

With Wasp, we have been looking at two things: inheritability and extensibility.
Extensibility would actually be interop that you mentioned -> can we allow people to combine/use existing parts of JS ecosystem together with Wasp, intermingled with Wasp?
And inheritability -> can we allow people to "eject" the code made by Wasp, so they can continue with it? We are mentioning that on our landing page.
In our case, extensibility is a must, while we would really like to have inheritability because it removes the "lock-in" effect, but we are aware it might be hard to achieve it, and its importance will be smaller and smaller as Wasp becomes more and more mature, so we are still evaluating how much time does it make sense to invest into inheritability.

text: Have you seen my project <https://ivanish.ca/hest-time-travel/|Hest>? It's very similar to what you're describing. And, the first prototype of it was built in CLJS, and there's a lot of Clojure philosophy in how I'm designing it.

Hest
? It's very similar to what you're describing. And, the first prototype of it was built in CLJS, and there's a lot of Clojure philosophy in how I'm designing it.

text: Oh that’s SUPER interesting, I’m going to have a proper read soon. What’s it written in now? Is it still browser based and just JS now?

elements.text: Oh that’s SUPER interesting, I’m going to have a proper read soon. What’s it written in now? Is it still browser based and just JS now?

text: And yes, lots of similar ideas! I want to be able to fly and explore the program in space, see calls travelling and be able to peek inside those calls and states

elements.text: And yes, lots of similar ideas! I want to be able to fly and explore the program in space, see calls travelling and be able to peek inside those calls and states

text: Also, on concurrency, I had a thought that threads were like stepping into another parallel world.

text: Or a slightly different looking layer to the world.

elements.text: Or a slightly different looking layer to the world.

text: It does seem like I’ve accidentally stumbled across essentially 60-80% overlap with Hest though.

elements.text: It does seem like I’ve accidentally stumbled across essentially 60-80% overlap with Hest though.

text:
Yeah, the current prototype is still JS. I'm keeping portability in mind as I design, with the thought that Hest should be sort of a _hosted_ system (similar to Clojure) that doesn't bake concrete details about the platform it's built atop into the conceptual design.

I feel like a lot of these ideas are obvious extensions of node-and-wire, and that a bunch of people will end up making tools like this. I think that'll be a good little scene, if it happens.

text: Ohhh yeah, thanks! I just can’t decide if I go simple and CLJS + web or try to learn something like Unity/Unreal to go down the VR route at a later date :thinking_face:

elements.text: Ohhh yeah, thanks! I just can’t decide if I go simple and CLJS + web or try to learn something like Unity/Unreal to go down the VR route at a later date

text:
The determining factor for me was that our existing tools are all web-based, and that's where the outputs of Hest will go. So there will always need to be a web version, in addition to whatever else I eventually make.

Beyond that... Unity is a good choice, but you need to learn a lot to make effective use of it, especially if you want it to play nicely with CLJ(S) — Arcadia notwithstanding. If you're already comfortable with the web, (CL)JS, and one of the graphics stacks (SVG, canvas, WebGL), you've already got _plenty_ of platform to prototype upon.

text:
I've been posting a few things, so I feel like its time for me to drop an introduction in here. My name is Aleks. I'm a software engineer living and working in Massachusetts. I went to school for game development, but fell in love with programming languages and web development along the way. I'm interested in building tools that make computers easier to use without paving over the underlying complexity of computing. I believe when there's a dissonance between what a program appears to be doing and what a computer is actually doing, it causes pain all up and down the stack - from end users to the folks designing the silicon.

I have a terrible track record of leaving projects unfinished, but I will include a link here to one of my more finished projects - a command line tool for working with tags the same way you would work with files. <https://github.com/alekslitynski/tagsystem>. Like everyone else here, I'm currently hacking on a visual programming system. I'm hoping to get it to a point in the next few months where other people could jump on board and participate in its development, if they want to.

This community seems wonderful, and I'm excited to dive into it.

text: Hi all! I’m a mostly self-taught web developer interested in GUI programming. I have that unfortunate type of personality very high in Openness and very low on Conscientiousness which means that I’m infinitely curious about a whole lot of things but I end up doing very little about it. My main interest around the topic of this Slack is the idea of a cross-platform GUI library that would allow the implementation of apps that would work wonderfully on all 3 big operating systems. I’m a huge fan of the work of Alan Kay at VPRI.
